docs.lead_paragraph: Medical insurance is often hard for many people to obtain. But relatives and friends of some teamsters' union officials in Brooklyn had no trouble getting it improperly, according to Federal investigators. The four top leaders of the union, Local 1205, were removed yesterday after an independent investigative panel charged that about 30 relatives and friends of the officials were able to qualify for the local's group medical plan after being recruited as fake union members. An audit by the panel found that the illicit members were allowed to use the plan even though the local's welfare fund had a deficit of $4.5 million last year and dental and eye-care benefits were cut for its 1,500 legitimate members.

headline.main: 4 Teamsters Officials Ousted Over Insurance Fraud Charge

docs.lead_paragraph: Nine months after its last president resigned amid intense debate over the organization's future, the Planned Parenthood Federation of America has chosen its new president, Gloria A. Feldt. Ms. Feldt, 53, who has headed Planned Parenthood's Phoenix affiliate since 1978, has firsthand experience with the group's core issues: raised in small-town Texas, she married at 15 and had her first child nine months later. "I love Planned Parenthood, I really love it, and from my own personal experience, I know the importance of our mission -- making sure that every woman can get reproductive health care, that women have the access and the legal right to make their own choices about childbearing," said Ms. Feldt, who had three children by the age of 20.

headline.main: Reasserting Its Identity, Group Picks New Leader

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission plans to revise antitrust guidelines that dictate what types of joint ventures doctors will be permitted to create. The chairman, Robert Pitofsky, says the commission, in cooperation with the Justice Department, will not relax the antitrust laws but will simply spell out how existing rules apply to health care. If Mr. Pitofsky delivers on that pledge, the commission will do consumers some good. But if, as some fear, the commission gives doctors special protections, it will do serious harm. The rapid growth of managed-care plans has forced an increasing number of doctors to sign up with the plans under terms that reduce their pay and autonomy. Managed-care plans have also forced hospitals to treat their enrollees at steeply discounted rates. One way for doctors to strike back is to band together, forming their own plans, joint ventures or loose associations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eager to perform a new eye procedure that experts say could generate as much as $10 billion in revenues, two groups of eye-care specialists are battling each other here and in other capitals over bills that will help to determine which side will control the market. On one side are optometrists, whose duties were once limited to eye examinations and prescribing glasses but who have been winning broader rights to diagnose diseases, treat them and prescribe drugs in 47 states.

headline.main: Optometrists Clash With Eye Surgeons Over Laser Process

docs.lead_paragraph: F.T.C. Plans to Simplify Rules on Doctor Networks With big mergers changing the face of the health care industry, the Federal Trade Commission plans to make it easier for doctors to band together, coordinate prices and form networks to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Doctors contend that such networks might encourage competition by providing alternatives to H.M.O.'s. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George Pataki has made a bold but flawed proposal to throw out New York's system of regulating hospitals. The plan starts off right -- ending price controls that encourage waste. But it would ruin many hospitals that cater to the poor and train medical residents. Mr. Pataki needs to enlarge his plan to subsidize these important functions. Albany now sets hospital rates for most patients. The rates are set high enough to cover not only the cost of treating insured patients, but also the cost of treating indigent patients and training residents. But the system is unraveling because patients are increasingly turning to health maintenance organizations and clinics, where price controls do not apply.

docs.lead_paragraph: With huge mergers changing the face of the health care industry, the Federal Trade Commission plans to make it easier for doctors to band together, coordinate prices and form networks to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. The new policy comes as many members of Congress are pressing the trade commission and the Justice Department to relax their rules on such joint ventures. The House Judiciary Committee recently approved a bill that would allow doctors to exchange information about their costs, fees and profits for the purpose of establishing a network to sell health care to patients or employers.

headline.main: DOCTORS MAY GET LEEWAY TO RIVAL LARGE COMPANIES
